title: Planning, Budgeting, and Forecasting
overview: This section represents 20% of the Part 1 exam and is the bridge between strategy and execution. It covers the entire planning cycle: from high-level strategic analysis (SWOT, Porter's 5 Forces) to the granular details of the Master Budget. Candidates must master forecasting techniques (regression, learning curves), budget methodologies (standard, flexible, zero-based, activity-based), and the complete sequence of operational and financial budgets. Success requires the ability to calculate variances, prepare pro forma financial statements, and evaluate the behavioral impact of budgeting choices.
bulletNotes: Strategic planning (5-10 years) sets the mission; budgeting (1 year) operationalizes it.
SWOT Analysis evaluates Internal factors (Strengths, Weaknesses) and External factors (Opportunities, Threats).
Porter's 5 Forces analyzes industry competitiveness and long-term profitability limits.
The Master Budget always begins with the Sales Budget (constrained by demand/capacity).
Production Budget = Sales + Desired Ending Inv. - Beginning Inv.
Regression analysis (y = a + bx) separates mixed costs into fixed (a) and variable (b) components.
R-squared (coefficient of determination) measures the reliability of the regression line (closer to 1 is better).
Learning Curve: doubling cumulative output reduces average time per unit by a constant percentage.
Expected Value is the weighted average of possible outcomes (Sum of Outcome x Probability).
Cash Budget excludes non-cash items like depreciation and bad debt expense (unless using direct write-off).
Flexible budgets adjust the static budget for the ACTUAL level of activity to measure efficiency.
Zero-Based Budgeting (ZBB) requires justifying every dollar from scratch, not just increments.
shortNotes: Focus on the logical flow: Strategy -> Forecast -> Master Budget. Memorize the 'Production Budget' formula—it's the key that unlocks Materials and Labor budgets. For forecasting, master simple regression interpretation and the high-low method. Understand that flexible budgets are the only fair way to evaluate performance. Be ready to calculate cash collections and disbursements, as liquidity questions are frequent.

concepts.title: 1. Strategic Planning & Analysis
concepts.content:
The Planning Cycle

Planning is the process of setting goals and determining how to achieve them. It moves from long-term (Strategic) to short-term (Tactical/Operational).

  • Strategic Plans (5-10 years): Broad, directional, set by top management. Focus on market positioning and long-term resource allocation.
  • Tactical Plans (1-18 months): Dept/Divisional level, implementing strategy.
  • Operational Plans (Weeks/Months): Day-to-day execution (e.g., production schedules).

Environmental Analysis Tools

SWOT Analysis:

  • Internal: Strengths (Patents, Brand), Weaknesses (High cost structure).
  • External: Opportunities (New markets), Threats (Competitors, Regulations).

Porter's Five Forces (Industry Analysis):

  1. Threat of new entrants: Barriers to entry (capital, regulations).
  2. Threat of Substitutes: Alternative products meeting same need.
  3. Bargaining Power of Buyers: Price sensitivity, volume.
  4. Bargaining Power of Suppliers: Concentration, switching costs.
  5. Intensity of Rivalry: Competition among existing firms.

BCG Growth-Share Matrix:

  • Stars: High Growth, High Share (Invest).
  • Cash Cows: Low Growth, High Share (Milk for cash).
  • Question Marks: High Growth, Low Share (Decide: Invest or Divest).
  • Dogs: Low Growth, Low Share (Divest).

concepts.title: 2. Budgeting Concepts & Methodologies
concepts.content:
Purpose of Budgets

Planning, Communication, Coordination, Motivation, and Control/Evaluation.

Budget Methodologies

MethodDescriptionPros/Cons
IncrementalBased on prior year +/- %.Simple but perpetuates inefficiencies.
Zero-Based (ZBB)Managers justify ALL expenses from $0.Eliminates waste but very time-consuming.
Activity-Based (ABB)Budgets costs based on cost drivers/activities.Links cost to output; complex to implement.
Rolling (Continuous)Add a month/quarter as one drops off.Always looking 12 months ahead; keeps planning active.
FlexibleAdjusts for actual activity level.Essential for performance evaluation (separates volume vs. efficiency).

Behavioral Issues

Budgetary Slack (Padding): Underestimating revenue or overestimating costs to make targets easier.

Authoritative (Top-Down): Faster, ensures strategic alignment, but lowers commitment.

Participative (Bottom-Up): Better accuracy, higher morale, but prone to slack and slower.

concepts.title: 3. Forecasting Techniques
concepts.content:
Regression Analysis

Used to separate mixed costs or forecast sales.

Equation: y = a + bx

  • y: Dependent variable (Total Cost / Sales)
  • x: Independent variable (Driver: Units / Ad Spend)
  • a: y-intercept (Fixed Cost)
  • b: Slope (Variable Cost per unit)

Correlation (r): Ranges from -1 to +1. Measures strength of relationship.

Coefficient of Determination (R²): % of change in y explained by change in x. (e.g., R²=0.90 means 90% accurate).

Learning Curve Analysis

Based on the principle that as workers gain experience, efficiency improves.

Cumulative Average-Time Model: As cumulative output DOUBLES, the cumulative average time per unit decreases by the learning rate percentage.

Example (80% Curve, 1st unit = 100 hrs):

  • 1 unit: 100 hrs avg (Total: 100)
  • 2 units: 80 hrs avg (100 * 0.8) (Total: 160)
  • 4 units: 64 hrs avg (80 * 0.8) (Total: 256)

Steady State: Learning stops when the machine pace or physical limit dictates speed.

Expected Value (EV)

Weighted average of outcomes based on probability.

EV = Σ (Outcome × Probability)

Used for decision making under uncertainty (Risk Neutral approach).

concepts.title: 4. Master Budget: The Operating Sequence
concepts.content:
1. Sales Budget

The foundation. Based on forecasted volume × selling price.

Everything else depends on this.

2. Production Budget (Units)

Determine units to produce to meet sales and inventory goals.

Units to Produce = Budgeted Sales + Desired Ending Inv - Beginning Inv

3. Direct Materials Budget

Usage Budget: Production Units × Material per Unit

Purchase Budget: Usage + Desired Ending Mat. Inv - Beginning Mat. Inv

Note: Purchases are in dollars and units; Usage is in units.

4. Direct Labor Budget

Production Units × Hours per Unit × Hourly Rate

5. Manufacturing Overhead Budget

Separates Variable (varies with driver) and Fixed (lump sum) portions.

6. Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) Budget

Combines DM, DL, and OH to determine the cost of products sold.

7. Selling & Admin (S&A) Budget

Period costs (R&D, Marketing, HQ).

concepts.title: 5. Financial Budgets
concepts.content:
1. Cash Budget

Crucial for liquidity. Identifies borrowing needs.

Structure:

  • Beginning Cash Balance
  • + Receipts (Inflows): Cash sales, Collections (lagged), Asset sales.
  • - Disbursements (Outflows): Purchases, Labor, Overhead* (less depreciation), Tax, Dividends.
  • = Preliminary Cash Balance
  • +/- Financing: Borrow if deficit; Repay/Invest if surplus.
  • = Ending Cash Balance

*Exam Trick: Always remove non-cash expenses like depreciation and amortization.

2. Pro Forma Income Statement

Projected Net Income based on all operating budgets.

3. Pro Forma Balance Sheet

Projected Assets, Liabilities, and Equity at end of period.

4. Statement of Cash Flows

Reconciles Net Income to Cash via Operating, Investing, and Financing activities.

formulas.name: Production Budget
formulas.formula: Budgeted Sales + Ending Inv - Beginning Inv

formulas.name: Materials Purchases
formulas.formula: Production Requirements + Ending Mat. Inv - Beginning Mat. Inv

formulas.name: Cash Collections
formulas.formula: (Current Month Sales × % Collected) + (Prior Month Sales × % Collected)

formulas.name: Standard Error (Se)
formulas.formula: Measures the dispersion of data points around the regression line

mistakes: Depreciation: Including it in the Cash Budget (It is a non-cash expense!).
Production Units vs. Sales Units: Confusing the two. Production must account for inventory changes.
Materials Usage vs. Purchases: Usage is for production; Purchases accounts for raw material inventory changes.
r vs. R-squared: 'r' is correlation (-1 to 1); 'R-squared' is reliability (0 to 1).
Learning Curve: Applying the curve to variable overhead or machine time (usually only applies to Direct Labor).
Slack: Assuming participative budgeting always leads to accurate budgets (it often creates slack).

quiz.question: Which of the following creates a 'ceiling' on the long-term profit potential of an industry?
quiz.explanation: Intense rivalry forces prices down and costs (marketing/R&D) up, squeezing margins and limiting industry profitability.

quiz.question: In the Master Budget sequence, which budget is prepared immediately after the Production Budget?
quiz.explanation: Once production units are known, the Direct Materials budget (and Direct Labor/Overhead) can be calculated. Sales is before Production.

quiz.question: A company uses a regression model y = 50,000 + 12x. What is the estimated cost at an activity level of 2,000 units?
quiz.explanation: Total Cost = Fixed Cost + (Variable Cost/unit * Units). y = 50,000 + (12 * 2,000) = 50,000 + 24,000 = $74,000.

quiz.question: Which budgeting methodology is best suited for discretionary costs and avoiding the 'use it or lose it' mentality?
quiz.explanation: ZBB requires justifying every expense from scratch, which helps eliminate unnecessary spending and prevents automatic increases found in incremental budgeting.

quiz.question: Using an 80% cumulative average-time learning curve, if the first unit takes 100 hours, what is the average time per unit after producing 4 units?

essay.question: Compare and contrast Top-Down (Authoritative) vs. Bottom-Up (Participative) budgeting. Which is generally preferred and why?
essay.modelAnswer:
Top-Down (Authoritative): Imposed by senior management. Pros: Fast, ensures alignment with strategic goals. Cons: Lower ownership/motivation from lower-level managers.

Bottom-Up (Participative): Lower-level managers provide input. Pros: Generally more accurate (they have local knowledge), higher morale/buy-in. Cons: Slower, prone to 'budgetary slack' (sandbagging).

Preference: Participative is generally preferred for motivation, but a hybrid approach (Iterative) is often best to balance alignment and ownership.
